item.title: How to become a foster parent in Indiana – RTV6 Indianapolis
item.description: Erin Lisch. Saturday, February 23, 2019 6:02 PM How to become a foster parent in Indiana. RTV6 Indianapolis. Retrieved from https://www.theindychannel.com/ How to become a foster parent in Indiana https://www.themoffettkids.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/116c99b542be4087a2cc53a23c0c8b6e_e_1080p-1.mp4 An event was held Saturday morning in Indianapolis to provide information on how people can help kids in foster care. INDIANAPOLIS — With the number of kids in Indiana in foster care continuing to climb, an event was held Saturday for the community to learn more about being a foster parent.

item.title: Johnnie L. Pennington Obit
item.description: Central Kentucky Obituary and Death Notices Collection KENTUCKY – Central Kentucky Obituary and Death Notice Collection – 234 Posted By: GenealogyBuff.com Date: Wednesday, 14 March 2018, at 2:01 p.m. Johnnie L. Pennington SHELBYVILLE, Ind. — Johnnie L. Pennington, 75, of Shelbyville died Wednesday at Community Hospital East in Indianapolis. Born Nov. 22, 1927, in Casey County, he was the son of the late Chester Pennington and Nillie Cole. He was an employee of Ford Motor Co.

item.title: English assignment on MLK turns into life lesson – Washington Times Herald
item.description: Lindsay Owens. Friday, January 16, 2017 10:00 PM. English assignment on MLK turns into life lesson. Washington Times Herald. Retrieved from http://www.washtimesherald.com/ * * For her MLK poster, Jen Hulsey chose to draw hands united. Hulsey and other students in Angel Zollars’ eighth grade English class at Washington Junior High created not only posters using quotes from the “I Have a Dream” speech by King, but also wrote about inequalities in America still today.

item.title: Stephanie Helton Email – Namesakes for the Children
item.description: I’m passing this along to you. Stephanie Helton, FCM – Martin Co.   Good Morning, Ms. Hulsey requested that I provide the namesakes for the children to you so that you can provide it to the foster/adoptive parents.   Dillan Levi – I choose Dillan’s first name the day he was born, the moment I saw his face the name came to me. I picked Levi as his middle name after a dear family friend who had passed, Dustin Levi Kelley.

item.title: Caron Hulsey to David E. Williams – Facebook Messenger
item.description: Facebook Messenger photo from Caron Hulsey to David E. Williams on June 9, 2016 at 6:22am

item.title: Caron Hulsey to David E. Williams – Facebook Messenger
item.description: Sorry to bother you,I’ve wanted to talk to you and your wife for months,have you gotten to adopt my grangchildren yet,if this hasn’t happened I would like Nicolle to sighn her rights over to you and your wife,it’s been hard fighting for them,having to let them go,it’s ts like they passed away,it’s st has affected Nicolle horribly,itststts painful for all of us,itststts feel there better having a good father figure,daniel is mental from his mother abusing him.

item.title: Nicolle Hulsey – Facebook Post
item.description: Hello everyone I’m so sorry that you all are going through this horrible tragedy. But I thought I was alone. I never wish the pain that I feel in my whole body on anyone in the world. Not even the caseworker that has led me down this road. I have (had) four beautiful babies and coming up in the beginning of July I’m signing my rights over. I have not gotten to speak or see my babies since 2014 my youngest was 6 months old then.

item.title: Open Arms Provides Hope for Kids – Christian Standard
item.description: Jennifer Johnson. Saturday, June 4, 2016 7:44 AM. Open Arms Provides Hope for Kids. Christian Standard. Retrieved from http://www.christianstandard.com/ Open Arms Provides Hope for Kids Open Arms provides homes, care, and education for children of all ages who have been neglected and abused. Most of all, Open Arms provides hope. The ministry, located in Switz City, Indiana, started as the Indiana Christian Children’s Home by a Johnson University grad named Bill Tucker more than 40 years ago.

item.title: Chelsea Wronowicz – Facebook Post
item.description: Every year, I make a deal with my 1st graders that if they ALL get 100’s on their Spelling test, I’ll do cartwheels and walk on my hands….they did it on Friday & today was the day I followed through. Yep…Might just be the last time I make that deal. Facebook Status Post by Chelsea Wronowicz on Thursday, September 24, 2015 at 3:13 pm

item.title: Kids’ Weather – Times-Mail
item.description: Kids’ Weather Thursday, September 10, 2015 Times-Mail * * Times-Mail Weather

item.title: Denise Dillman – Facebook Post
item.description: Facebook Status Post by Denise Dillman on Thursday, August 27, 2015 at 11:03 am Day 11 in kindergarten! When doing our calendar activities every day, we look at the date, predict patterns, identify the weather and add to our weather graph, talk about events that are happening today, tomorrow, next week, etc., and identify shapes. We sing about the days of the week (to the tune of “The Addams Family”), months of the year (tune of “Ten Little Indians”) and the seasons (tune of “The Ants Go Marching”).

item.title: Denise Dillman – Facebook Post
item.description: Wednesday, August 26, 2015 11:13 am – Denise Dillman | Facebook Our special visitor in kindergarten today was Zero the Hero. Without him, we could only count to 9! By adding a zero, we can make more and more numbers. Your child colored a picture to show you what Zero the Hero looks like. (He is a pop up puppet.) Each 10th day, when he visits, we sing his song to get him to appear, we do some sort of activity, and we write numbers.

item.title: Denise Dillman – Facebook Post
item.description: Tuesday, August 25, 2015 11:17 am – Denise Dillman | Facebook Another busy day in kindergarten! (At least no emergency drills today.) We have used our Syllable Book to practice writing letters and counting syllables. This is only the second time we have done this so far (A page, and now the B page), and the kids have already caught on to the procedure! We celebrated Black Day by telling about the black items that we brought or wore.

item.title: Denise Dillman – Facebook Post
item.description: Monday, August 24, 2015 11:51 am – Denise Dillman | Facebook The week has gotten off to a great start! We introduced the letter ‘B’ this morning when our letter puppet, Marvin the Mouse, brought the ‘B’ letter cards for us. Marvin is a little shy; he will only whisper to me and I have to tell the kids what he said. After making sure we knew how to write the letter and what the sound was, we practiced.

item.title: Denise Dillman – Facebook Post
item.description: Friday, August 21, 2015 11:47 am – Denise Dillman | Facebook Kindergarten fun: This morning we learned the song ‘Tooty Ta’. In addition to the giggles and laughs, the kids are learning to listen and follow directions. We started our ‘Oreo Cookie Book’, using the word ‘am’. Whenever we introduce a new word that has 2 letters, we call this an ‘Oreo cookie word’ and write it in our book.

item.title: Denise Dillman – Facebook Post
item.description: Thursday, August 20, 2015 12:03 am – Denise Dillman | Facebook More great times in kindergarten! We started our Special Person of the Day this morning. The Special Person (SP) unscrambles the letter of his/her name using the magnetic letters. Then we do a cheer using their name, with the SP leading the cheer. (Only boys with muscles can be cheerleaders; look at IU or any other college.:>). Next we interview the SP to learn about some of their favorite things (learning to ask questions) and describe that person (learning observation skills).

item.title: Denise Dillman – Facebook Post
item.description: Wednesday, August 19, 2015 11:04 am – Denise Dillman | Facebook We are having our first birthday celebration in kindergarten today. (I won’t name names on Facebook, but your child should know who.) This morning we sang ‘Happy birthday’, using the word cards. The birthday child then mixed up the cards and we had to read them in the new order and then sing them. :>) We also formed a circle around the b-day child and an inflatable birthday cake, while we sang “Zippity Doo Dah” (‘plenty of wishes going —‘s way’) and then clapped 6 times for 6 years old.

item.title: Denise Dillman – Facebook Post
item.description: Tuesday, August 18, 2015 11:42 am – Denise Dillman | Facebook Another great morning in kindergarten! The kids went to PE this morning with our PE teacher. (Thanks to all of the parents for remembering to have your kids wear their tennis shoes!) Tomorrow they will get to go to Music Class and are asked to wear/have tennis shoes again. We also had a Chester Chase this morning. Upon reading “The Kissing Hand”, we found a note from Chester, the raccoon, in the back of the book, telling us to go to the office.

item.title: Denise Dillman – Facebook Post
item.description: Monday, August 17, 2015 11:13 am – Denise Dillman | Facebook To my kindergarten parents: We have had another great day! The kids are doing a wonderful job remembering our procedures and things are going very smoothly! We did a reading lesson this morning, learning about the words “I” and “am”. We started our journals with the letter ‘a’. As we do every day, we did our calendar activities on the bulletin board, and then worked in our calendar book.

item.title: Denise Dillman – Facebook Post
item.description: Friday, August 14, 2015 11:02 am – Denise Dillman | Facebook Just to let everyone that has kids in my classroom – we have had a WONDERFUL morning. No tears and a lot of smiles! (I’m not going to tag people because I might forget someone, so feel free to tag anyone that you think is interested.) The kids are at lunch right now and will have recess afterwards. Then it’s rest time, reading “Chicka Chicka Boom Boom”, and starting our own “How Many Coconuts?

item.title: Paying it forward – Washington Times Herald
item.description: Lindsay Owens. Thursday, April 30, 2015 7:00 AM. Paying it forward. Washington Times Herald. Retrieved from http://www.washtimesherald.com/ Paying it forward WHS students doing good deeds for those in need Washington High School students in Barb Knepp’s health classes have joined with students involved in Choice for Change, a student group working to create a more positive atmosphere at WHS, to pay it forward throughout the month of May. Participating students will receive three “Pay It Forward” cards and are asked to do three nice things for people in the community.

item.description: Lindsay Owens. Monday, March 30, 2015 2:25 PM. Learning to save lives. Washington Times Herald. Retrieved from http://www.washtimesherald.com/ * * Joshua Hulsey practices on a CPR dummy during health class at Washington High School. Kelly Overton | Times Herald Students required to learn CPR Students in health classes at Washington High School have spent the days leading up to spring break learning something that could impact lives forever, CPR.

item.title: Daviess County Sheriff’s Report – Loogootee Tribune
item.description: Daviess County Sheriff’s Report Thursday, March 26, 2015 Loogootee Tribune … Mar 18, 2015 – Nicole Hulsey, 23, of Washington, was arrested and charged with manufacturing methamphetamine, maintain a common nuisance, possession of a hypodermic syringe, possession of paraphernalia, possession of marijuana/hashish, and possession of methamphetamine. Bond was set at $15,000. Mar 18, 2015 – Daniel Moffett, 27, of Shelbyville, was arrested and charged with manufacturing methamphetamine, resisting law enforcement, possession of marijuana/hashish, maintaining a common nuisance, and possession of paraphernalia.

item.title: Meth bust – WAMW 107.9 FM
item.description: Meth bust Thursday, March 19, 2015 WAMW 107.9 FM Two people were jailed in Washington for making meth and other charges on Wednesday. Washington police logs state officers got into a foot pursuit on Dewey and South Meridian at 5:22-pm on Wednesday. 27-year-old Daniel Keith Moffett was apprehended on Southeast 1st. During the investigation, police interviewed 23-year-old Nicole Hulsey. Later a state police lab team was contacted and after search warrants were obtained and served, both Moffett and Hulsey were arrested for manufacturing meth, possession of marijuana and maintaining a common nuisance.

item.title: Daviess County Arrests – WWBL 106.5 FM
item.description: http://www.wwbl.com/daviess-co-arrests/ by John Szink on March 19, 2015 Washington Police arrested 27-year-old Daniel Moffett of Shelbyville Wednesday for Manufacturing Methamphetamine, Resisting Law Enforcement, Possession of Marijuana and Paraphernalia and Maintaining a Common Nuisance. Bond was set at $12,000. City police also arrested 23-year-old Nicole Hulsey of Washington Wednesday for Manufacturing Meth, Maintaining a Common Nuisance, Possession of a Hypodermic Syringe, Paraphernalia, Marijuana and Methamphetamine. Hulsey is being held without bond.

item.title: Juanita F. Creighton Obit
item.description: Juanita Creighton, 67, of Shelbyville, died Friday, March 5, 2010, at Heritage House Convalescent Center. Born May 28, 1942, in Shelby County, she was the daughter of William Roscoe and Elise Louise (Conway) Kendall. Survivors include daughters, Benita (husband, Mark) Jessup and Rebecca Moffett, both of Shelbyville, and Tammy (husband, Robbie) Helm of Lakeland, Fla.; sister, Patricia (husband, Dick) Graves of Shelbyville; seven grandchildren; and five great-grandchildren. She was preceded in death by her parents; a sister, Carolyn Cutsinger; and a brother, Kenneth Kendall.

item.title: Washington Times Herald – Births Published the Week of July 13 to 18
item.description: The Washington Times Herald Monday, July 20, 2009 Births Published the Week of July 13 to 18 View Births published the week of July 13 to 18 PDF Dillan Levi Moffett Nicolle Leann Hulsey and Daniel Keith Moffett announce the birth of their son, Dillan Levi Moffett. He was born at 1:38 a.m. July 1 at Daviess Community Hospital. He weighed 8 lbs., 1 oz. and was 21 inches long.

item.title: Dustin Levi Kelley (1988-2007) - Find A Grave Memorial
item.description: Dustin Levi Kelley (1988-2007) View Dustin Levi Kelley (1988-2007) PDF Birth: 20 Dec 1988 Death: 8 Oct 2007 (aged 18) Burial: Fairmount Cemetery, Huntingburg, Dubois County, Indiana, USA Plot: Cremation Memorial ID: 22154856 Dustin (18) died at about 10:30 am Monday in an automobile accident near the Huntingburg Conservation Club. He was born in MI to Karen Kelley of Huntingburg & Anthony McNeely of Washington. Surviving are his father, Anthony McNeely, and step-mother Anita McNeely of Washington; two brothers, Nathan & Zachary McNeely of Washington; one sister, Tosha McNeely of Huntingburg; three step-brothers, Daniel Eversole, Zachary Eversole and Dalton Moore of Washington; grandfather Carl Thomas McNeely of Washington; grandmother Francis McNeely of Bicknell; four uncles, Andrew McNeely and Jeff Lowe both of Evansville, Mark Petry of Dale, and Michael Petry of Huntingburg, two aunts, Clarissa Collins of Odon and Carla White of Bicknell; mother Karen Kelley of Huntingburg; grandparents Buck & Mary Kelley of Huntingburg, two uncles John Kelley of Florida and Keith Kelley of Texas; two aunts, Kim & Kay Kelley of Holland.

item.title: 18-Year-Old Dies In 1 Car Wreck – WBIW 1340 AM
item.description: WBIW 1340 AM 18-Year-Old Dies In 1 Car Wreck (HUNTINGBURG) An 18-year-old Huntingburg man is killed after launching his car off the roadway and hitting a tree. Indiana state police say Dustin L. Kelley of Huntingburg was driving his Chevy on County Road 100 West just north of the Huntingburg Conservation Club when he reportedly crested a hill, ran off the west side of the road, over-corrected sending him off the east side of the roadway and became airborne.

item.title: Washington Times Herald Obituaries – Dustin’s Story
item.description: Dustin Kelley View Dustin Kelley PDF Dustin’s Story HUNTINGBURG – Dustin Levi Kelley, 18, died at about 10:30 a.m. Monday in an automobile accident near the Huntingburg Conservation Club. He was born in Michigan to Karen Kelley of Huntingburg and Anthony McNeely of Washington. Surviving are his father, Anthony McNeely and stepmother Anita McNeely of Washington; two brothers, Nathan and Zachary McNeely, both of Washington; one sister, Tosha McNeely of Huntingburg; three stepbrothers, Daniel Eversole, Zachary Eversole and Dalton Moore of Washington; grandfather, Carl Thomas McNeely of Washington; grandmother, Frances McNeely of Bicknell; two aunts, Clarissa Collins of Odon and Carla White of Bicknell; three uncles, Andrew McNeely and Jeff Lowe, both of Evansville, Mark Petry of Dale, and Michael Petry of Huntingburg; mother, Karen Kelley of Huntingburg; grandparents, Buck and Mary Kelley of Huntingburg; two uncles, John Kelley of Florida and Keith Kelley of Texas; two aunts, Kim and Kay Kelley of Holland.

item.title: Washington Times Herald – Veale Tosses Perfect Game for Hatchets
item.description: Veale tosses perfect game for Hatchets View Veale tosses perfect game for Hatchets PDF If Kendra Veale ever wondered just how well she could pitch, then a quick viewing of the Barr-Reeve-Washington gametape might give her a pretty good indication. Veale tossed a perfect game, mowing down all 21 Lady Vikings she faced on Thursday at the Sports Complex. “She pitched a heck of a game and we gave her the game ball after the game,” said WHS coach Alan Lemon.

item.title: Washington Times Herald – Veale Tosses Perfect Game for Hatchets
item.description: The Washington Times Herald Friday, May 11, 2007 11:39 am Todd Lancaster, Sports Editor Veale tosses perfect game for Hatchets View Veale tosses perfect game for Hatchets PDF If Kendra Veale ever wondered just how well she could pitch, then a quick viewing of the Barr-Reeve-Washington gametape might give her a pretty good indication. Veale tossed a perfect game, mowing down all 21 Lady Vikings she faced on Thursday at the Sports Complex.

item.title: Washington Times Herald – Hatchets Blast Past Shoals
item.description: Hatchets blast past Shoals View Hatchets blast past Shoals PDF What’s better than back-to-back triples? Back-to-back triples, followed by an inside-the-park home run. And that is exactly what the Hatchet softball team experienced, during a a 12-0 drubbing of Shoals on Monday at the Sports Complex. And as coach Alan Lemon likes to say, “They hit the ball with hardness.” The triples from Kendra Veale and Michelle Hulsey, was followed by the dinger from Kiersten Hinkle in a first inning that saw the Hatchets score 11 runs on 10 hits.

item.title: Washington Times Herald – Hatchets Blast Past Shoals

And as coach Alan Lemon likes to say, “They hit the ball with hardness.

item.title: Washington Times Herald – Hatchets Down Lady Lions
item.description: Hatchets Down Lady Lions View Hatchets Down Lady Lions PDF The Washington Hatchet softball team started the week playing well against North Daviess and finished it playing even better, with the season’s first win, a 6-0 win over Loogootee. The Hatchets (1-7) used a five-run fifth inning to break away from what had been shaping up as a pitchers duel, to secure the win over their Martin County foe.

item.title: Washington Times Herald – Hatchets Down Lady Lions
item.description: The Washington Times Herald Friday, April 13, 2007 10:23 pm Todd Lancaster, Sports Editor Hatchets Down Lady Lions View Hatchets Down Lady Lions PDF The Washington Hatchet softball team started the week playing well against North Daviess and finished it playing even better, with the season’s first win, a 6-0 win over Loogootee. The Hatchets (1-7) used a five-run fifth inning to break away from what had been shaping up as a pitchers duel, to secure the win over their Martin County foe.

item.title: Washington Times Herald – Hatchets, Cougars Battle at Complex
item.description: Hatchets, Cougars battle at Complex View Hatchets, Cougars battle at Complex PDF Michelle Hulsey of Washington waits for a throw as a North Daviess runner breaks for second, in the Lady Cougars 6-2 win on Monday at the Sports Complex. Todd Lancaster | The Washington Times Herald The North Daviess Cougars and the Washington Hatchet softball teams showed that softball played in early April can sometimes be just as interesting as the late May variety, as the Cougars and Hatchets kept each other on their collective heels for six innings on Monday at the Sports Complex.

item.title: Washington Times Herald – Drawing A Crowd
item.description: Drawing a crowd These Washington High School NJROTC cadets drew an attentive crowd while spending part of their summer vacation practicing in front of the Hatchet House at Bedford Road and Seventh Street on Thursday morning. Cadets (from left) are Adam Van Winkle and Adam Chestnut exchanging rifles. At right are cadets Christian Meyer and Ariza Miyasi. Watching in the foreground are (from left) Derek Bruce, Mike Hulsey and Cody Simmons.

item.title: Washington Times Herald – Drawing A Crowd
item.description: The Washington Times Herald Friday, July 21, 2006 12:10 pm Mike Myers Drawing a crowd View Drawing a crowd PDF [][1] These Washington High School NJROTC cadets drew an attentive crowd while spending part of their summer vacation practicing in front of the Hatchet House at Bedford Road and Seventh Street on Thursday morning. Cadets (from left) are Adam Van Winkle and Adam Chestnut exchanging rifles. At right are cadets Christian Meyer and Ariza Miyasi.

item.title: Hatchets Fall at Sectional
item.description: {{.Title}} {{if .Params.author}} — {{.Get "Params.Author" }} DeW{{end}} ### Hatchets fall at sectional View Hatchets fall at sectional PDF Amber Criswell of Washington watches Whitney Hill (5) and Michelle Hulsey from the dugout at Pike Central on Monday. Todd Lancaster | Washington Times Herald PETERSBURG — The Washington Hatchet softball team ended its season with a pair of bookend losses to Princeton. The first loss came on Friday night and 72 hours later the Hatchets also dropped the Pike Central Sectional opener 13-0, to end a season that tallied just two wins, but showed improvement throughout the entire second half.

item.title: Washington Times Herald – Hatchets Fall at Sectional

item.title: Lady Cardinals slip to 3-11 – Greene County Daily World
item.description: Greene County Daily World Lady Cardinals slip to 3-11 Lady Cardinals slip to 3-11 Host Washington scored eight runs in their half of the second inning as the Lady Hatchets defeated Bloomfield 10-5 in a high school softball game Friday. Freshman Cassie Wells, who pitched in relief of starter Cassie O’Neall, suffered the loss for the Lady Cardinals (3-11). Wells’ record dropped to 0-2. Sophomore Kim Keys had a double for Bloomfield, who will play at 5 p.

item.title: Lady Miners defeat winless Washington – Greene County Daily World
item.description: Greene County Daily World Lady Miners defeat winless Washington Lady Miners defeat winless Washington Linton pounded out 10 hits as the Lady Miner softball team defeated winless Washington 7-2 Wednesday at home. Izzy Carpenter tossed a three-hitter, earning her 10th victory in 16 decisions. She struck out seven and walked one. The Lady Miners (12-8) committed one error. “We played a much better game defensively than we did the night before against Shakamak,” said Linton coach Jill Flater.

item.title: BNL waxes Washington – Times-Mail
item.description: Jeff Bartlett | Times-Mail BNL waxes Washington BNL waxes Washington WASHINGTON – With Washington winless in nine starts and Bedford North Lawrence unblemished in four, Tuesday’s softball tilt at glistening Gwaltney Sports Complex was a big-time mismatch on paper. The Stars made sure it remained a mismatch on the field as they pounded 14 hits and rolled to a 15-2, five-inning triumph. “I’m glad that they took care of business,” said BNL coach Mike Matlock.
